The mountains may be higher in the counties to the east, but the Catskills are everywhere in Delaware County. If it seems there are more of them than there are people, it's because Delaware has the lowest population density of any county in New York outside of the

. Most of the residents live in or near the small villages and hamlets that seem to sprout anywhere enough level ground can be found, usually along the two upper branches of the river that gives its name to the county in return for its waters, impounded in the county to create

's two largest reservoirs. Along those rivers, and between the villages, you will see the large dairy farms that make up the backbone of the Delaware County economy.

While for most travelers Delaware County is a large open space passed through on the way to somewhere else like
or
, those who take the time to stop there can discover the hidden charms of upstate New York at its most rural, from sweeping mountain and valley vistas to the quiet country charm of a tidy

. Outdoor enthusiasts in particular will find much to sample and return to later—with most of the county's wildlands outside of the Catskill Park, hunting is more accessible. Trout fishermen take to their boats in Cannonsville and Pepacton reservoirs, and their waders in the East and West branches below them, sometimes even daring the Delaware's main stem below Hancock. Mountain bikers, skiers and hikers can find less beaten paths in various corners of this quiet yet welcoming county. And for those who'd prefer something less strenuous but equally rewarding, the village shopping districts remain largely untouched by time.

Delaware County is the Catskills for those who really do want to get away from it all. In the past that has included the likes of U.S. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who made the Pindars Corners farm he summered at his legal residence. In the future it could easily include you, as well.
Delhi, the county seat, is pronounced not like
but with a long "i" at the end, as "DELL-high."

As much as it is described as rural, Delaware County is just as often referred to as remote for a very good reason—it actually is. There is no scheduled passenger air service to any airport nearer than Binghamton, although there are two general-aviation airports on the northwest corner of the county. Nor is there any passenger rail service anywhere nearby that could be called convenient. So if you plan to visit, you'll be coming by road, most likely in a car.
There was once commercial passenger service to
, just outside the county, but no more. Still, it's ideal for the private pilot who wants to visit.
, the county's only airport, is smaller.

Two of the state's freeways pass through the periphery of Delaware County.
, slowly being upgraded into

, connects the county with Binghamton to the west and the New York metropolitan area to the southeast, closely following the Beaver Kill and both branches of the Delaware as it does. This is the most traveled route to and from the county, winding through scenic and rugged countryside largely unpopulated save for the village of Hancock. There are still at-grade intersections in some areas; the state is slowly closing them or building overpasses to meet interstate standards.

On the northwest fringe,
passes through the county, including
, its most populous community. It's the most common way of reaching that corner of the county from Binghamton, and the best approach overall when coming from the
at the northern end. Like NY 17/I-86, it follows the headwaters of a major river, in this case the Susquehanna.
is a parallel two-lane road for those who prefer that.
and
reach Delaware County going south from the

area. The former runs mostly past farms and woods from Sidney south to where the two roads jointly end at NY 17 in Deposit. Route 10 offers more varied scenery, following the Delaware's West Branch from near its source north of Stamford down through Delhi and Walton, along Cannonsville Reservoir to Deposit.

Drivers willing to trade a slower approach for a more direct route into central and northeastern Delaware County from the Hudson Valley to the east have two surface roads to choose from. After an equally scenic trip across northern Greene County,
basks at the foot of the mountains along the northern fringe of the county between Grand Gorge and Stamford, detouring into
for a few miles as it does. Drivers can pick it up either from the New York State Thruway at Catskill, or via NY 23A, which merges with it near
after coming through the ski towns of Tannersville and Hunter. West of Stamford, it passes through less populated country before merging with NY 28 just east of the I-88 exit at Oneonta.
After an equally scenic trip up the Esopus Creek valley from Kingston,

passes Fleischmanns and Arkville to Margaretville. There it turns west, passing through Andes en route to Delhi en route to Oneonta. This is the most direct route to Delaware County from the Hudson Valley.

Another approach from the north,
, tops the scenic Schoharie Creek valley it passes through in

with a gorgeous panorama of Grand Gorge and the mountains behind it shortly after it crosses the Delaware County line. Behind a tire shop south of the village the East Branch of the Delaware rises; NY 30 follows it down to Margaretville and then along Pepacton Reservoir to Downsville, finally ending at NY 17 where the Beaver Kill empties into the East Branch in the eponymous hamlet.

A leisurely drive up the Delaware's main stem along
through

brings traffic into Delaware County's lightly populated southern corner. It pulls farther away from the river here, with tiny settlements like Lordsville reachable via side roads before it reaches Hancock and its northern terminus at NY 17. For those coming from the adjoining areas of
, this, or

, which also ends at Hancock, may be the best approach.

If you are coming from the northwest and wish to avoid Binghamton,
leaves Interstate 81 at the

exit. Passing through mostly farm country with no major settlements, it works its way into Delaware County as it heads due east. There, it intersects NY 8 at the small hamlet of Masonville on its way to Walton and Downsville in the county's southeast. From its southern terminus at NY 17 in the Sullivan County hamlet of
, it also serves as a more direct route to those two communities.

As you might imagine from the previous section, there is no public transportation of any kind in Delaware County. Not even a bus network, other than the stops Adirondack Trailways makes. So, you'll most likely be getting around in a car again.

Most of the county's local road network is maintained by it or the towns they pass through. There is one state highway entirely within the county.

connects Hancock with Cannonsville Reservoir. However, at times of heavy rainfall in the past, such as 2006, it has been closed off due to landslides and flooding, so check beforehand if there has been such weather recently.

value: http://nysparks.com/historic-sites/3/details.aspx John Burroughs Memorial State Historic Site

, on Burroughs Road off NY 30 south of Grand Gorge. Delaware County's only designated National Historic Landmark commemorates the life and death of native son Burroughs, who pioneered modern nature writing in many of his bestsellers of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The site of the farm where Burroughs grew up, it is also home to Woodchuck Lodge, where he spent his later years, and his final resting place.

While none of the Catskills' 35 High Peaks are in Delaware County, there are still rewarding hikes available. The western corner of the Catskill Park in the county's east offers gems like Barkaboom Mountain and Dry Brook Ridge amid its hundreds of acres of state-owned "forever wild" Forest Preserve. Elsewhere in the county is the 7,000-acre
http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/85850.html Bear Spring Mountain Wildlife Management Area

, along Route 206 between Walton and Downsville. Outside Stamford, it is sometimes possible to drive the road to the top of Mount Utsayantha and its sweeping views—if not, it's an easy hike. The long-distance Finger Lakes Trail also offers possibilities, particularly in
http://www.cnyhiking.com/FLT-BarbourBrookStateForest.htm two state forests at the county's southwest corner

is the premier mountain-biking route in the county. It follows 26.5 mi (42.6 km) of old railroad right-of-way through river valleys and spectacular scenery from Bloomville through Stamford over to Grand Gorge and down to Roxbury. Horses and of course hikers are also welcome. Snowmobilers and cross-country skiers use the trail in winter.

Bear Spring and the Catskill Park wild forests are also especially popular with hunters. New York's annual deer season is held in November and December; there are longer small-game seasons and a wild turkey season in the spring.
for those from out of state are higher than for residents.
File:Cannonsville Res. Sands Creek Rd. Hancock, NY.JPG
If water-based recreation is more your thing, consider visiting either

, impoundments of the West and East branches of the Delaware respectively, built to supply New York City in the mid-20th century. Cannonsville, located in the winding valleys between Walton and Deposit, has the largest basin of the city's reservoirs, while Pepacton, between Margaretville and Downsville, holds the most water. Unpowered boating and fishing are permitted on them with
http://www.nyc.gov/html/dep/html/recreation/boating.shtml a free permit from the city's Department of Environmental Protection

Neighboring Sullivan County may have the historical claim to being the birthplace of American fly fishing, but southern Delaware County has most of the waters. As you follow Route 17 west from Roscoe on a good day during the season (April 1–October 31), you'll see anglers casting for trout in the lower Beaver Kill and the East and West branches of the Delaware.
http://www.dec.ny.gov/permits/6091.html Licenses from the state's Department of Environmental Conservation
, whether for a day or year, are available from many local sporting-goods stores for a reasonable price, whether resident or out-of-state. Local guide services are available as well.

Despite all the mountains, downhill skiing has had a tough go of it in Delaware County, due to the remoteness of the area and the competition offered by more accessible resorts to the east. Right now the only area operating is
in the northeast corner of the county, near Roxbury and Grand Gorge. If you can't ski or board and aren't willing to learn, Platekill offers inner tubes for rent as well.

Drive carefully on secondary and tertiary roads if you are unfamiliar with them, particularly when they are unpaved. Many of them were built to serve local farms, not visitors, so they take steep slopes and sharp turns. Should you have an accident assistance is some distance away and will take time to arrive; cellular phone coverage may not even be available.

This advice goes doubly or triply for those roads in adverse weather conditions. Some dirt roads have signs noting that they are not maintained in wintertime. If your vehicle is not equipped with four-wheel drive it would be wise to consider an alternate route.

Heavy rainfall can also turn some of those roads into quagmires. Even paved roads are not immune, if they travel through narrow gaps between mountains at any point. NY 268 has been closed for months at a time in the wake of major storms due to flooding and landslides, for instance.
